page.title: 16The Abbey.
page.content: Little now remains of the old Priory and Abbey, although the old fish ponds, now largely overgrown are still in evidence near the railway bridge. The foundation date of the Priory is uncertain, although it is known that the Prior in 1442 was called William. By the end of the 15th century, the status of the Priory had changed to that of an Abbey, and in the years before the Dissolution it became very wealthy. In 1539, the Abbey was dissolved and the buildings and lands passed into the hands of Sir Maurice Berkeley, Standard Bearer to King Henry VIII. The Berkeley family made the Abbey into a fine mansion and in 1620, King Charles I was entertained there. After the serious fire in 1763, it passed to the Hoare family, who owned it until 1786, when it fell into disrepair, before collapsing.
